Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Design and Operations of Supply Chain for Cleaner Fuels: Models, Algorithms and Implementation for Coal-fired Power Plants

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to establish a comprehensive characterization of fuel supply chain systems in power plants, and to develop analytical models and efficient algorithms to support them to design and operate those chains with cleaner fuels. Fuel blending has been widely adopted among coal-fired plants to produce a blend satisfying heat and emission standards, which requires power plants to manage their complex fuel chains to ensure that the right fuel is available at the right time. Such a situation is more complicated when non-traditional biomass is included for co-firing. To resolve this pressing issue, this research will: (i) collect and analyze real data to identify critical and random factors; (ii) build comprehensive fuel supply chain models using stochastic programming and/or robust optimization methods; (iii) develop efficient algorithms to compute optimal/near-optimal solutions for practical instances; (iv) demonstrate the effectiveness of those models and algorithms on achieving an optimal balance among emission reduction, economic efficiency and reliability in power generation.

If successful, this research will provide a set of substantial tools that will significantly improve the design and operation of coal-fired power plants and their fuel supply chains. The estimated savings nationwide could be multi-billion dollars annually. More broadly, these tools can be utilized in biomass integration, economic analysis of retrofit technologies, and contract negotiations. They are also applicable to other industries, such as chemical and food industries. Our research findings will be disseminated timely via conferences, journal publications and a dedicated internet page containing relevant tools, models, case studies, and tutorials/manuals. Undergraduate and graduate students will also benefit from this award through new course material and research involvement. The transformative impact will be generated through the close collaboration with industrial partners and student interns.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we have worked with industrial collaborators to comprehensively and analytically study the fuel supply chain system for power stations running coal fired generators.  With more stringent regulations on power generators and serious concerns on pollutions, traditional coal fired power plants must be selective on purchasing coals and other fuels, design feasible and satisfactory blending recipes, and build and manage the complicated supply chain to ensure that the right fuel is available at the right time for blending with the least cost.  To address this sophisticated issue, we have deeply investigated all major operations in the whole chain, identified critical factors and decisions, constructed a large-scale mixed integer model, and finally developed a comprehensive decision support system with user-friendly input and output interfaces to manage a fuel supply chain.  Through benchmarking with the actual practices using real data from an industrial collaborator, it is observed that several million dollars can be saved annually in fuel procurement and management.

We have also studied two theoretical models abstracted from the fuel supply chain research when random factors are considered. One is the chance constrained stochastic mixed integer program, which includes the chance constrained lot-sizing model underlying our decision support system as a special case.  Many valid inequalities and associated cutting plane algorithms, which are stronger than most existing results, have been developed to achieve the fast computation. Another one is the reliable p-median problem, which resembles the location problem of blending facilities. Robust optimization formulations have been developed, along with an efficient decomposition algorithm to handle practical instances.

Additionally, during the project period, teaching materials on linear program modeling for blending and power flow problems have been created and refined for undergraduate Operations Research courses. They have been well received by undergraduate students due to the interesting background and real impact. Also, industrial experts’ presentations and field trips have been arranged for students to train the next generation workforce. A couple of veteran students have been involved in and supported by this project through a supplement for veterans, which helps them build a deeper understanding and train them with necessary skills and tools. Moreover, a few doctoral students have been partially supported by this project, including a female one.

Research and the developed system have been actively disseminated through academic conferences, major fuel acquisition conferences, and a demonstration and tutorial workshop for local utilities.
